item.title: Around 4 in every 10 adults finding energy bills difficult to afford
item.description: Around 4 in every 10 adults finding energy bills difficult to afford 22 September 2023 Around 4 in every 10 (42%) of adults in Great Britain report they are finding it very or somewhat difficult to afford energy bills. This is according to those asked between 6 and 17 September 2023 as part of our latest Public opinions and social trends bulletin. This was slightly lower than 48% in a similar period last year (31 August to 11 September 2022). Among the 56% of people who said their cost of living had risen in the previous month, 60% said the price of their fuel had increased. Almost half (47%) said they were using less fuel such as gas or electricity in their homes because of the rising cost of living. item.title: Number of businesses fell in the year to March 2023
item.description: Number of businesses fell in the year to March 2023 27 September 2023 The number of Value Added Tax (VAT) and/or Pay As You Earn (PAYE) businesses in the UK as of March 2023 was 2.727 million, a decrease of 1.5% from March 2022. Through the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, the business population remained broadly steady but is now showing a small fall. While growth in the number of businesses has slowed since 2018, this is the first annual fall since 2010 to 2011. The numbers of businesses within all categories of legal status fell except for local authorities and non-profits. The professional, scientific, and technical industry accounted for the largest number of businesses, with 15.2% of all registered businesses in the UK. This was compared with 15.6% in March last year. The number of businesses in this industry has decreased for four years running, but it remains the largest broad industry group since 2013. The transport and storage (including postal) broad industry group experienced the largest fall in the year to March 2023. After strong growth in 2021, the number of transport and storage businesses has fallen in the last two years, with a decrease of 6.9% in 2023. Read our latest bulletin, UK business; activity, size and location: 2023 ü†ï Back to the top More than half a million jobs in green industries in 2020 27 September 2023 In 2020 there were an estimated 526,000 full-time equivalent (FTE) people employed in green industries in the UK, compared with 507,000 FTE in 2015. In 2018, there was a peak of 545,000 FTE. A green job is defined as employment in an activity that contributes to protecting or restoring the environment. These can be jobs in green industries, jobs in green occupations or jobs in green firms. Looking at green occupations, analysis of recent responses to our Opinions and Lifestyle Survey in May 2023 found that around a quarter (27%) of working adults in Great Britain would describe any part of their job as a ‚Äúgreen job‚Äù. Meanwhile, around 1 in 20 working adults (4%) reported that all or most of their job relates to ‚Äúgreen‚Äù activities. Working males (30%) appeared more likely than working females (24%) to describe any part of their job as green. In Scotland and Wales, working adults were more likely to describe any part of their job as green, at 38% and 36%, respectively, while 26% of working adults in England said the same. item.title: UK business investment revised up in April to June 2023
item.description: UK business investment revised up in April to June 2023 29 September 2023 UK business investment increased by 4.1% in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2023, revised up from the provisional estimate of 3.4% growth. This reflects upwards revisions to investments in transport, intellectual property products (IPP), and information and communication technology (ICT) and other machinery and equipment. Business investment has grown by 9.2% compared with the same quarter a year ago. Whole economy investment (technically known as gross fixed capital formation), which includes investment by business and public sector investment, increased by 0.8% in Quarter 2 2023. This was revised up from the provisional estimate of 0.0% growth. The largest contribution to growth in the latest quarter came from transport, with a smaller positive contribution coming from intellectual property products. Business investment, after lagging behind whole economy investment for much of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and the period after, is now closing the gap. item.title: Rent or mortgage payments up for nearly half of adults
item.description: Rent or mortgage payments up for nearly half of adults 06 October 2023 Almost half (47%) of adults in Great Britain paying rent or a mortgage said their payments had increased in the last six months. This is according to those asked between 20 September and 1 October 2023 as part of our latest Public opinions and social trends bulletin . This was 33% during a similar period last year (29 September to 9 October 2022). Among rent and mortgage payers, 40% said they were finding the payments very or somewhat difficult to afford. That was compared with 30% a year ago. Read our latest Public opinions and social trends bulletin ü†ï Back to the top

item.title: UK GDP estimated to have grown by 0.2% in August 2023
item.description: UK GDP estimated to have grown by 0.2% in August 2023 12 October 2023 Monthly real gross domestic product (GDP) is estimated to have grown by 0.2% in August 2023, following a fall of 0.6% in July 2023. Looking at the broader picture, GDP increased by 0.3% in the three months to August 2023, with growth in all sectors. Services output grew by 0.4% in August 2023, after a fall of 0.6% in July 2023, and was the main contributor to the growth in GDP in July. Output in consumer facing services fell by 0.6% in August 2023 following a fall of 0.2% in July. Production output fell by 0.7% in August 2023, following a fall of 1.1% in July 2023. The construction sector declined by 0.5% in August 2023, following a 0.4% decrease in July 2023. Imports from EU countries fell by ¬£0.2 billion, while imports from non-EU countries rose by ¬£1.0 billion. The rise in imports from non-EU countries was mainly the result of higher imports of oil and gas. After removing the effect of inflation by calculating "chained volume measures", total goods imports decreased by ¬£0.4 billion (1.1%) in August 2023. This was because imports from the EU fell by ¬£0.7 billion (3.2%) while imports from non-EU countries rose by ¬£0.3 billion (1.7%). Total exports of goods decreased by ¬£0.7 billion (2.2%) in August 2023, because of a ¬£0.7 billion fall in exports to non-EU countries, while exports to EU countries remained stable. After the effect of inflation is removed, total goods exports fell by ¬£1.3 billion (4.6%) in August 2023. Exports to non-EU countries decreased by ¬£1.0 billion (7.2%) and exports to EU countries fell by ¬£0.2 billion (1.8%). The total trade in goods and services deficit narrowed by ¬£3.5 billion to ¬£10.4 billion in the three months to August 2023, as imports fell by more than exports.
